of the spiral in which they commence. The same entire absence, or very small size, of the central
elevation, together with the uniformity, or even slight increase of
thickness towards the circumference, also helps us to separate
<u>Orbitolite</u> from <u>Orbitoides</u>; the centre of the latter being always
considerably elevated, and the thickness of its disk ordinarily
diminishing gradually towards its margin <s>.</s> [<u>Note</u> I wish this
statement to be understood with reference to the genus <u>Orbitoides</u> as
characterised by the structure which I have shown it to possess.
(Quart. Jour. of Geol. Soc. Febr. 1850), and not to the genus as defined
by M D'Orbigny, (Cours Élémentaire de Palaeontologie Tome ii p.194)
who, notwithstanding that he has shown himself to be acquainted
with my Memoir (by copying from it a figure of Nummulite),
has not profited in any degree by my investigations, but has
left the generic characters of <u>Orbitolites</u>, <u>Orbitolina</u> and
<u>Orbitoides</u> in the state in which they might have been, and probably were, before
that Memoir was published. The true distinction, however,
has been fully recognised by M D'Archiac, who in his "Description
des Animaux Fossiles du Groupe Nummulitique de L'Inde" p.349, <s>has</s>
